data.title: PopupMenu submenu arrow is misplaced
data.body:
Tested on Godot 2.1.2 and master
Windows 10 64 bits

The following test code:

```gdscript
	var menu = PopupMenu.new()
	menu.add_item("One")
	menu.add_submenu_item("Submenu", "Submenu")
	add_child(menu)
	var submenu = PopupMenu.new()
	submenu.add_item("Apple")
	menu.add_child(submenu)
	menu.popup()
```

Produces a menu with sub-menu, but the arrow is not included in the calculation of the width, making it overlap with the text:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1311555/25364109/1db70f40-2960-11e7-9616-3e2fe9d0c8ad.png)

A workaround is to manually hardcode the size of the menu.

data.title: Manipulators for non-uniform scaling in 3d viewport?
data.body:
Arch Linux, all Godot versions

Are there any plans to add manipulators for scaling objects non-uniformly in the 3d scene editor (scale mode) or maybe shortcuts to confine operations to certain axes like e.g. in blender? Right now there are only gizmos for translation and rotation, though scale is apparently always set uniformly. if you want to scale an object only by one or two axes, it's currently only possible via the inspector.

data.title: Bug: Using variables with set_layer_mask_bit in PhysicsBody2D
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 10
Godot 2.1.2-stable win64

**Issue description:**
When using a variable passed by another function to change a single mask bit it changes the layer equal to twice the variable value instead.

**Steps to reproduce:**
```
func set_physical_layer( layer)
    set_layer_mask(0)
    set_layer_mask_bit(layer, true)
    set_layer_mask_bit(2, false)
    var m = get_layer_mask()
```
I realize that this code does nothing practical, it is just an example to show the problem. If you were to call this function using the using an integer of 2, you should expect m to return 0. However, when a variable is used to set the mask bit instead of entering a specific value. it actually changes the bit equal to twice the integer value. For example if layer = 2 then set_layer_mask_bit(layer, true) actually sets bit 4 of the mask to be true instead of bit 2, layer = 1 sets bit 2 and so on with the pattern being twice the passed value. I don't think this is intended to work this way as the documentation indicates that an integer is the expected type of the function set_layer_mask_bit and even if it is supposed to change twice the value for some internal reason, then passing a hard value like 2 should change the same bit as layer = 2.

data.title: Create and distribute a press kit on the Godot website
data.body:
[It was suggested by a Q&A user](https://godotengine.org/qa/1702/can-anyone-give-ideas-on-how-increase-the-popularity-of-godot?show=14384#a14384) that there should be a downloadable press kit available somewhere on the Godot website. It could then be linked to in the site footer.

## What it could contain

- Logos (in color and monochrome versions, PNG and SVG formats at least)
  - Logo + Text (one with text besides the icon, one with text below the icon?)
  - Icon
- Logo usage guidelines

## Examples and inspiration

- [Blender](https://www.blender.org/about/logo/)
- [Unity](https://unity3d.com/public-relations/brand)

and many other things you can imagine
I know it may require some hard work but (in my opinion) it deserves
what do you think?

data.title: Screen real estate: reducing the margins between containers
data.body:
godot 3.x all OSs'

I would like the huge boarders on the godot windows to go away, they just take a lot of screen realestate and make me feel claustophobic...it is the little handles on the edge of the windows...if you look at blender 3D the individual windows have not boarders, maybe a 1 pixel line separator and it helps with that "oh so cramped" feeling...
the areas marked with red lines are the areas I am referring to..I feel they can just go away.
![window_boarders](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/27959760/25339783/18bfb69c-2904-11e7-86a9-03d9984e3e64.png)
I hope this is the correct place to post this, as it feels more like a bug tracker....the link on the godot dev forums took me here though...so???

data.title: 3.x 3D tools - Exporting level mesh for other 3D editors (like fbx, collada, obj...)
data.body:
Ability to export Godot scene meshes (collisions also) to some intermediate format like obj, fbx, collada so it can be opened in external 3D editor at least for reference.

It's super important feature which most engines often ignore...
Usually game Level Design and most of Level Art is made in editor tools. Often there is a need to export geometry made in Editor Tools or Level assembled in Godot Editor to external 3D creation program, so models can be created in some context of the game.
Constant exporting WIP models and uploading them and them opening Game Editor to see how it looks is a big hassle.

data.title: 3.0 Shaders - Allow combining written shaders with visual ones?
data.body:
(actually written with written also xD)
This is probably more topic for a discussion, than an issue (there is no visual shaders in 3.0 yet :D)

Would it be possible to combine written shaders with visual ones (written also)? For example useful in scenario like this one:
1. Technical Artist wrote Uber Shader that is used for most of the assets in current production. It has all shading features props in this production need. (Wet Surface, Rain, Wind Effect, Under Water Effect, Normal Sharpening and such)
2. There is Enviro Texture Artist that wants shader that mixes textures in cool way and he wants to send them for production main Uber Shader that Tech Artist made.

Would that be possible? It's basically making two shaders communicate data between them.

I assume there might be technical limitations or drawbacks, but I'm not an expert :B

data.title: Extensions for Godot
data.body:
# Extensions

After talking to @touilleMan and @reduz in Paris (it was awesome!!!) I'm writing down this proposal.

GDNative is a nice way to use third party libraries in your game or just optimize performance critical code, but it *could* also be used to add "extensions" to Godot (for the lack of a better name, "plugin" and "add-on" are already taken  )

## Current situation

A GDNativeScript represents *one class* in a GDNativeLibrary. To have any effect, this script must be attached to any object. This is cool to write game code or wrap third party code in a class.

The current way to "extend" Godot is via plugins (or more precisely, "editor plugins"). These plugins can do a lot of awesome things, but they all only run in the editor. GDNative scripts can be used to make plugins as well, but they can't do anything that will have an impact on the running game.

## Proposal

![extension](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5209613/25318699/7d9c0810-2894-11e7-865f-c4ceae5f6c84.png)

Have a new project settings tab for "extensions". Extensions are GDNativeLibraries that don't need to expose any classes, they just get run and that's it.

These extensions get loaded at startup, in the editor as well as in a game.

### Implementation of an extension

A regular GDNativeLibrary, but it contains a special function `godot_native_extension_init` and `godot_native_extension_terminate` that get called at startup and shutdown of Godot.

The C API (modules/gdnative/godot.h and modules/gdnative/godot/*) will contain new functions, like `godot_extension_register_importer(godot_extension_importer *importer)`. The `godot_extension_importer` type would just be a struct with function pointers.

### Loading and installing

A new directory called "extensions" containing subfolders for the different extension. In those folders a file "extension.cfg" or something like that. This file specifies the GDNativeLibrary to use to load the extension.

```
- extensions
    - fbx_loader
        - extension.cfg
        - fbx_library.tres
    - python_language
        - extension.cfg
        - python_library.tres
```

When the editor or game starts the extensions get loaded.

The Asset Lib could feature a new type of asset: "extension" and install that in the right place.
Once installed then the extension would get initialized, editor restart should not be required. (the Asset Lib downloader needs to initialize the initialization process  )

### Use cases

* downloadable scripting languages in the AssetLib (with editor support)
* new resource importers
* possibly more that I can't think of right now  

-----

WDYT?

data.title: [3.0] CurveTextureEditor allows making curls: bug or feature?
data.body:
Godot master

I gave a try at the CurveTextureEditor, and I found it allowed making loops, or "overhanging" parts, which is normally only allowed in actual 2D curves, which this one isn't because it is supposed to save to a texture with only one row of pixel values. But with such loops you would end up with two Y values to choose for one X value.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1311555/25318356/44080ef2-288d-11e7-83a7-9138d140259d.png)
Is it a bug or a feature?

Note: I was considering to re-use this editor, as I started to work on a Curve resource for https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/7296
however I might end up not to, because features between the two differ.

data.title: Right-clicking a folder in the FileSystem panel should give an option to "Show In File Manager"
data.body:
Right-clicking a file in FileSystem's Icon view will give you the option to Show In File Manager:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/27100585/25318230/ccd98180-28cd-11e7-94bc-39f43ae49414.png)

This is really useful for when you want to drop in some assets into the same folder, but I think this behaviour should be extended to folders in the folder tree view. As it is, Godot 2.1.3 shows no menu when right-clicking a folder, and 3.0 only gives the option to expand and collapse all folders:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/27100585/25318289/96f657fe-28ce-11e7-82b3-4335833480de.png)

data.title: re-added MultiScript
data.body:
Based on the talk I had with @reduz in Paris:

The very first Godot version (when it was open sourced) had "MultiScript" which lets you use multiple scripts on one object.
With the addition of mulitple new scripting languages (VisualScript, soon C# and GDNative) it can be of use to combine scripts rather than delegating (with huge maintainance cost) or creating child nodes
which could impact performance.

I used the code from 0b806ee as the base and made it work with the current master.

data.title: Unable to run exported binary on macOS 10.12.4.
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:** 

macOS 10.12.4, Godot 2.1.3

**Issue description:**
<!-- What happened, and what was expected. -->

Export a blank scene, and got the following messages when running.

`The application "a.app" can't be opened.`

**Steps to reproduce:**

1. Create a new project.
2. Add a `Control` Node, and save the scene.
3. Export to `Mac` target with default setting.
4. Run the exported binary.
